byline.contributor: Michael Schwirtz and Jeffrey E. Singer contributed reporting.
byline.original: By KIM BARKER, COLLEEN WRIGHT and J. DAVID GOODMAN

abstract: Artist and bow-tie designer Tyrelle D Shaw, driven by feelings of rejection, attacked at least four women of Asian descent in Manhattan before committing suicide in elevator shaft; talented but troubled 25-year-old came from broken home.
lead_paragraph: Tyrelle D. Shaw, a budding artist and bow-tie designer, seemed to be overcoming his difficult upbringing, until feelings of rejection drove him to assault at least four women before staging a gruesome last act.

headline.main: How a Life That Showed Promise Veered Into Violence Against Asian Women
headline.print_headline: How a Life That Showed Promise Veered Into Violence, Then Death

snippet: Tyrelle D. Shaw, a budding artist and bow-tie designer, seemed to be overcoming his difficult upbringing, until feelings of rejection drove him to assault at least four women before staging a gruesome last act.
